paragraphs.text: Nope! San Antonio’s shots fell like summer rain in second half. David Lee got loose inside, putting San Antonio up four with a whirling layup, and then Anderson blocked Buddy Hield’s wild layup attempt, the kind of shot that Sacramento lived off of in the first half. Patty Mills hit back-to-back jumpers (a 3, then a 2-pointer plus the foul). Then it was Danny Green’s turn to hurl consecutive daggers. The 114–104 win was San Antonio’s 50th of the season, making this the 18th consecutive year the Spurs have reached the half-century mark. Gregg Popovich worships Satan.

paragraphs.name: a25c
paragraphs.text: Monroe has been rejuvenated by a move to the bench, where he has been given the freedom to anchor the second-unit offense and not do as much on defense. Last season, the Bucks tried to integrate the lumbering Monroe into an aggressive scheme that asked their big men to hedge and recover on screens past the 3-point line. They weren’t forcing a square peg through a round hole so much as through a hole that didn’t even exist. But Monroe is playing closer to the basket this year, and the Bucks are funneling penetration to him rather than asking him to move his feet in space.

paragraphs.name: bbe1
paragraphs.text: The Celtics bested the Warriors by out-Warriorsing the Warriors. It took an inspired effort from the entire rotation, but Boston proved that it has the weapons to disrupt the Warriors’ modern game plan. Add this game to the memo on how to beat the Warriors: play smart and so fucking hard that you scare Kerr into making weird decisions in the name of conserving his stars. Beat the Warriors by daring them to beat themselves.

The garment in question is a black hooded sweatshirt, printed with competing images of a map of the United States, Martin Luther King, and a starred-and-striped lightning bolt. It comes from Milan-based designer Neil Barrett and retails for $569. (Import taxes included.) Normally I’d be all the way in on NBA players wearing Barrett, who’s been a certified king of this kind of bold leisurewear for more than a decade. And while I appreciate the sentiment of wearing an ultra-patriotic hoodie at this contested moment in American politics, it must be said: This sweatshirt is trash. MLK? A hero. America? 6/10, would patriate again. And lightning bolts? Reliably great. But throw them together, and you get a hoodie that’s trying too hard, worn by two players doing the same. (If you really want to signal “I am wealthy and will wear literally anything, but I have good taste,” try this one. Way better.) So: Who wore it best? No one. No one did.

c8e367631b29.title: Celtics lost to the Raptors without Lowry and then proceeded to the lose to the Suns and Lakers.

paragraphs.name: 6b7d
paragraphs.text: Celtics lost to the Raptors without Lowry and then proceeded to the lose to the Suns and Lakers. Beating the Warriors on an off night doesn’t make the terrifying. As a Raptor fan, I am far more scared of Washington than I am of Boston. Their weaknesses are still glaring. No rebounding, no secondary scorer (aside for Olynyk) and poor defensively with Thomas.

However, when bashing on them for losing to the Suns and Clippers, it is important to remember that they didn’t have Horford & Bradley for the Suns game and didn’t have Horford & Jerebko for the Clippers game, leading to…

813a09243a26.title: Lotta Celts criticism in the comments.

paragraphs.name: 917c
paragraphs.text: Lotta Celts criticism in the comments. As a Blazers fan, what I see when I watch the East this year is that Boston matches up better against the Cavs (doesn’t mean they’d win a 7-game series) than they do vs. the Raptors, and a lot better than they match up with the Wiz. As someone else noted, at least the Cavs might have to play two tough series to reach the Finals this year.
